item.title: 'Collect the data and share the data:' How can game companies support women with leadership ambitions?
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

November 5, 2025

4 Min Read

Why aren't there more women in leadership roles within the game industry and what is the solution? It's a question former Sony Santa Monica director of product development, Meghan Morgan Juinio, and Gearbox Montreal executive producer Fleur Marty grappled with during an on-stage conversation at Gamescom Asia x Thailand Game Show. 

First, Juinio provided some context to explain why answering that question is so important. She noted that, according to the Entertainment Software Association's latest 'Annual Facts' report on the U.S. video game industry, around 205 million Americans currently play video games—and 47 percent of those players identified as women. 

But how many women are building video games?

The latest GDC State of the Industry survey found that around 25 percent of developers identified as women. Discussing that data, Juinio questioned how many of those respondents were game directors or studio heads? How many are executives sitting at the top of the table, making decisions about which titles get funded? 

"I think over the past five to ten years, collectively around the world, we've put a great amount of effort and energy into bringing more girls into STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). We've created more pathways for girls in high school and university to have mentorship and internship programs that create pathways for entry-level roles in the game industry," said Juinio. 

Related:Sumo Group-owned outsourcing studio Atomhawk closes Canadian branch

"We want to continue that, but I believe this is a 'yes and' conversation here. So, now what? How do we bring more women along to influence the content that gets into the hand of the players?" 

To find out, I took advantage of a Q&A session to ask Juinio and Marty how major publishers and studios—such as the ones that promoted them into senior positions—can take practical steps to help women who wish to pursue leadership roles? 

"If you don't ask the question you'll never know"

Juinio said there are many opportunities for companies to put their best foot forward in that regard. "One of them, which is quite basic, is to collect the data and share the data with hiring managers," she explained. 

"I'm not advocating for quotas or for top-down forced [hiring policies] that dictate what the team makeup needs to look like from a gender perspective, but If your hiring managers don't have awareness of what the makeup of the teams look like, how can they be part of the evolution we want to inspire here? So collect the data and share the data." 

She added that employers should also strive to find and nurture cohorts of like-minded women within their studios by establishing development programs that allow women from different disciplines to connect. "Maybe there's one female engineer on Team A and two female animators on Team B and one female designer on Team F, way over there," Juinio continued. "But do they know each other? Do they have opportunities to meet and connect? I think really looking to foster connection and support and this sense of community will really help women to be stronger." 

Related:The Persona 5 series has sold over 13 million copies

Marty agreed and noted how, when she worked at Warner Bros. Montreal, she kickstarted a Slack channel called 'Women of Warner' to unite women from different disciplines. 

"At the time, developers were very separated from QA—because QA was on the publishing side and handling all of the titles for the company, while devs were just at Warner Montreal," she recalled. 

"But I said 'no, anybody who worked at Warner Montreal should be part of this and it allowed a lot of the women in QA to connect with devs and ask them questions. It's so simple and it's free and it's the most basic thing, but allowing that connection [helps]." 

Marty added that companies should be proactive in identifying women who want to pursue leadership opportunities to figure out how to meet their specific needs. "Not everybody wants a leadership role," she added. "Some people are happy to remain individual contributors and experts, but if you don't ask the question you'll never know. So identify them and then ask 'what's the path [for this person]? What does that look like?' and start building."
